course.subject: PHYS
course.name: Computational Methods in Physics
course.description: This course provides an introduction to basic numerical and symbolic computation. Topics include methods of interpolation and extrapolation, approximation methods of root finding, numerical integration and solving ordinary differential equations, symbolic algebra and calculus. Students need to write computer codes in laboratory sessions and write lab reports to describe their results.
course.prerequisites: (COMP 1021 OR COMP 1029P) AND (MATH 2352 OR PHYS 2124)

reviews.author: ChuaWanZhen
reviews.title: A good introductory course to Computational Physics
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers the basic computational tools to do calculations for physics problems. Content:

1. Integral & Derivatives
2. Linear & Non Linear Equations
3. ODE
4. PDE

Be sure to attend lectures and copy everything that he writes on the whiteboard

WARNING: He would test students on what he teach during the lectures and those are not included in the lecture notes. So be sure to copy them or have someone to copy it for you
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr Choy is passionate in teaching. Although he can't speak very fluent English, but he tries to make everything clear to everybody. He would keep reminding us about the date of our exams and to bring the scientific calculator for the exams. It would be a disaster if you do not have a calculator for the exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is very good. This course is graded by:

Final: 40 %
Midterm: 30 %
Lab: 30 %

The exams do not test us on python coding. It tests on how the computer does the calculation. For example: You cant use the traditional way to solve for eigenvalues and eigenvectors during the exam, you have to use the QR algorithm, which is the method that is used by the computer to solve it.

Also, be careful if the angles of sin and cosine functions are in radian, you have to switch the mode in your calculator when doing the calculations. Otherwise, you would get everything wrong.

In my opinion, it would be very helpful if you can use the scientific calculator well (How to store answers and keep on doing further calculations). As there is limited time to do the calculations.

The exam would not be very difficult if you attend all the lectures and pay attention in class.
reviews.comment_workload: There is a lab assignment each week. The lab assignments are basically writing python codes to do the calculations. So be sure to be familiar with python before taking this course. The workload is quite heavy and it normally takes a day to work everything out.

reviews.author: A0
reviews.comment_content:
Basically, its a MATH course + little bit COMP.
But still need to learn how these math stuff is applied to physics problems.

Syllabus:
Numerical Integrals
- Trapezoidal Rule
- Rectangular Rule
- Other Integration Rule
- Romberg Integration
- Gaussian Quadrature
- Errors in Numerical Integration
- ...

Numerical Differentiation
- Forward Difference
- Backward Difference
- Central Difference
- Errors in Differentiation
- ...

Linear / Non-Linear Equations
- Linear Algebra
- Gaussian Elimination
- LU Decomposition
- QR Decomposition
- Relaxation
- Binary Search
- Newton's Method
- Golden Ratio Search
- ...

Ordinary Differential Equations
- Euler's Method
- Runge-Kutta
- Leapfrog Method
- Bulirsh-Stoer Method
- ...

Partial Differentiation Equations
- Jacobi Method
- Gauss-Seidel

Random Processes
- Random Numbers
- Monte Carlo
- Monte Carlo Integration
- Buffon's Needle
- Markov Chain Monte Carlo
- Metropolis Algorithm
- Ising Model
- ...

Actually, the contents before the mid term are very easy as the contents have been taught in math calculus class and linear algebra class.

Python is used as a programming language for assignments, but no coding questions in exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Really Good Grade.
40% Assignments
30% Midterm Exam
30% Final Exam

Midterm: 100/100, Mean: 90.6
Final: 44/100, Mean: 50

The grades are determined by the final exam since most people get almost full marks for mid term, and 80/100 or above for assignments (Except the one with Columb Drag.....)

Below mean for final and got a B+, really good grade.

The professor even said he wanted to give A ranges for all the student XD.
reviews.comment_workload:
One programming assignment per 1.5 week. 7 assignments in total.

The programming assignments are quite time consuming if you are not familiar with python or programming in general. And debugging is annoying.

But answers for some questions in the assignments can be found on Github.

One assignments in particular is quite difficult which is the Columb Drag. Just didn't know how to do it and gave up.

Mid term is super easy, most people can get 100/100, 90something if there are some careless mistakes. Because the questions are just straight forward maths.

For final the professor said: "Do not worry! There is no very difficult math problems. It will be very easy if you understand these I emphasized many times in the class."

In reality: Quite hard. Questions are not as straight forward as the mid term exam. You really need to think how the question should be done.

reviews.author: RickyPang
reviews.title: Good introductory course for computational method
reviews.comment_content:
Integrations methods
Numerical Differentiation
Matrix with Linear algebra
ODE
PDE
Monte Carlo
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Liu is a passionate professor.
reviews.comment_grading:
Seems quite good

For your reference:
Midterm : 100/100
Assignment: almost full marks
Final: 60/100

Outcome: A-
reviews.comment_workload: There are 7 assignments in this course which include all the topic. Each assignment has 1.5 or 2 weeks for you to compute, However, writing program and debugging are quite time consuming. Hence, the workload increases. However, if the assignment has lots of questions , the TA will teach some of them during lab session so that no need to worry. Besides, you need to write a short report to show the key results of the assignments. But no need to write a very formal report. Just 1 page with all figures and some short captions are fine.

reviews.author: Dove
reviews.comment_content: The course includes four chapters: integration & derivative; linear & non-linear equation; ODE; PDE. This is a mandatory course for physics major students, and its contents are useful for computational techniques.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor likes to use whiteboard to write notes (concepts, examples, etc.) so it is a good idea to take your own notes. You can basically cope with all assignments and exams using his notes without extra effort. It was a pity that he got sick at the end of the semester so the last part of PDE was not taught (but he offered a make-up lecture after the final exam). Hope the pace of the lecture could be a bit faster.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair. The lab assignments are intended for practice so don't worry about grading.
reviews.comment_workload: You only need to attend the lectures and finish all lab assignments (once a week, 2-3h) to get A range.

reviews.author: varnaiyer
reviews.comment_content: The content of this course is very useful for any physics student. Standard techniques of numerical analysis such as various computational methods in integration, solving non linear equations, differential equations etc. is covered. The course modules are accompanied by lab work which is very useful to gain familiarity with these methods.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. Choy is very systematic and provides excellent notes summarizing what has been covered in class. If you want more depth it is wise to attend his lectures. More often than not it's what's covered in class that appears in the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite linient with 20% of the class getting in the A range. The exams are quite simple and test the application of computational methods in simple problems with possible analytic solutions.

The distribution of marks is as follows:

Lab 30%
Midterm 30%
Final 40%
reviews.comment_workload: The workload primarily stems from labwork due once every week. The initial labs are very simple while they tend to get more cumbersome towards the end. The course as such does not have much content that one really needs to memorize as cheat sheets are allowed in the exam.

reviews.author: Seabass
reviews.title: Do not do your own project, idiot assessment method
reviews.comment_content:
The contents are really easy, nothing special.
Solving the following problems in the numerical method.

1. Integration
2. Monte-Carlo
3. Differentiation
4. ODE & PDE

Except for the Monte-Carlo process, MATH1023 MATH1024 will be a better choice. Do not expect to learn those really cool coding.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Passionate, but not worth your time to attend the lectures.
You better learn from the internet by yourself.
Go to YouTube and watch the tutorial from India will be a better choice.

He will give u some messy PowerPoint that you can hardly learn from it.

You should better studied CM,EM,QM and SM before you enroll in this course because those model will be used WITHOUT any useful reference.

Also, he will use a whiteboard, write everything on an FXXKING whiteboard. Every time you attend a lecture is an eye-testing.  His camera is usually out-focus and you cannot read. He does not read the zoom chatting a lot, so it is useless to tell him through ZOOM.

But it is worth mentioning that he is passionate about teaching (Although you can hardly learn from it).
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment 40%
Final project 60%

I've got full from my assignment and 70/100 in the final project.
The mean for assignment is roughly 85% and the mean for the final project is 63/100
I got a B+.

It seems the grading is pretty good, but I would tell you that it is not FAIR.

There was a weekly assignment. You have to write a code to solve the problem.

For assignments, you better write as SHORT as possible. What I had done for almost all of my assignments (except the first assignment) was writing down the calculation result and posting my code. No explanation, no discussion. It resulted in full marks. What my friend did is a clear explanation for his codes, discussion on calculation error and complexity of his codes. And he got only ~80%. Basically, those TA are really lazy and you better give them the minimum workload.

For the final project, you got 2 options. One is doing what he gives. Just like doing assignments. Another option is to do your own project.

I will suggest you do not do your own project since it may too difficult for TA to understand. If they do not know what are you writing, they will give you a poor result.

The final project is much worse than assignments. It has almost NO grading standard. I have attached the 'Grading guidelines'.

The grading system can be summarized as ' more effort you put, less return you get'.
reviews.comment_workload:
Since attending lectures is pretty useless, you can skip them. (And you better skip them to save your time for learning on YouTube)

Those assignments are usually based on the modeling never explained in the lesson, so you have to spend time on the internet to learn them by yourself. An example is that you have to use the Ising model to do the calculation. Fyr., Ising model is only taught in PG Thermodynamics.

Base on the 'more effort you put, less return you get' principle, the workload can be small.(if you know the modeling)
